Optimal Gradient Compression
for Distributed and Federated Learning

â€ƒâ€ƒAlyazeed Albasyoni â€ƒâ€ƒMher Safaryan â€ƒâ€ƒLaurent Condat â€ƒâ€ƒPeter RichtÃ¡rik

Abstract

Communicating information, like gradient vectors, between computing nodes in distributed and federated learning is typically an unavoidable burden, resulting in scalability issues. Indeed, communication might be slow and costly. Recent advances in communication-efficient training algorithms have reduced this bottleneck by using compression techniques, in the form of sparsification, quantization, or low-rank approximation. Since compression is a lossy, or inexact, process, the iteration complexity is typically worsened; but the total communication complexity can improve significantly, possibly leading to large computation time savings. In this paper, we investigate the fundamental trade-off between the number of bits needed to encode compressed vectors and the compression error. We perform both worst-case and average-case analysis, providing tight lower bounds. In the worst-case analysis, we introduce an efficient compression operator, Sparse Dithering, which is very close to the lower bound. In the average-case analysis, we design a simple compression operator, Spherical Compression, which naturally achieves the lower bound. Thus, our new compression schemes significantly outperform the state of the art. We conduct numerical experiments to illustrate this improvement.

1 Introduction

Due to the necessity of huge amounts of data to achieve high-quality machine learning models [27, 35], modern large-scale training procedures are executed in a distributed environment [5, 36]. In such a setup, both storage and computation needs are reduced, as the overall data (potentially too big to fit into a single machine) is partitioned among the nodes and computation is carried out in parallel. However, in order to keep the consensus across the network, compute nodes have to exchange some information about their local progress [31, 17, 4]. The demand of information communication between all machines in a distributed setup is typically a burden, resulting in a scalability issue commonly referred to as communication bottleneck [28, 40, 23]. To reduce the amount of information to be transferred, information is passed in a compressed or inexact form. Information lossy compression is a common practice, where original information is encoded approximately with essentially fewer bits, while introducing additional controllable distortion into the decoded message.

In the context of Federated Learning [21, 24, 15], communication between devices arises naturally, as data is initially decentralized and should remain so, for privacy purposes. Actually, it might be desirable for each unit, or client, to compress/encode/encrypt the information they are going to share, in order to minimize private data disclosures. Another practical scenario where compression methods are useful is when storage capabilities are scarce or there is no need to save complete versions of the data. In such cases, the representation of the data (encoding and decoding schemes) can be optimized and with little or no precision loss, one can allocate significantly less memory space.

1.1 Related Work

Recently, substantial amount of work has been devoted to the advances of communication-efficient training algorithms by utilizing various types of compression mechanisms, such as sparsification [38, 37, 10], quantization [1, 39, 13] and low-rank approximation [36]. Typically, the information communicated by computing nodes consists of local gradients, to which compression operators are applied. For example, one popular example of such compression operator is Top-kğ‘˜k [3], which transfers only kğ‘˜k coordinates of the gradient with largest magnitudes.

The theoretical foundation of lossy compression has long history and is based on Rate-Distortion Theory introduced by Shannon in his seminal papers [29, 30]. Recently, rate-distortion theory has been utilized in the context of model compression [12, 8]. In contrast to this, another line of research is devoted to the lossless compression methods which is rooted in Shannonâ€™s source coding theorem [9]. Both approaches exploit statistical properties of the input messages for analyses, which differs from our setting.

We investigate the problem of lossy compression, namely encoding vectors xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} without prior knowledge on the distribution, for any dâ‰¥1ğ‘‘1d\geq 1, into as few bits as possible, while introducing as little distortion as possible. Formally, we measure the distortion of a (possibly randomized) compression operator ğ’:â„dâ†’â„d:ğ’â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathcal{C}\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} by its constant Î±âˆˆ[0,1]ğ›¼01\alpha\in[0,1] such that ğ”¼â€‹[â€–ğ’â€‹(x)âˆ’xâ€–2]â‰¤Î±â€‹â€–xâ€–2ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormğ’ğ‘¥ğ‘¥2ğ›¼superscriptnormğ‘¥2\mathbb{E}\left[\|\mathcal{C}(x)-x\|^{2}\right]\leq\alpha\|x\|^{2} for every xğ‘¥x, where the norm is the Euclidean norm (see Definitions 1, 2 and 3 for details). We denote by bğ‘b the number of bits (in the worst case or in expectation) needed to encode ğ’â€‹(x)ğ’ğ‘¥\mathcal{C}(x). Intuitively, bğ‘b and Î±ğ›¼\alpha cannot be too small at the same time: they are antagonistic and ruled by a fundamental rate-distortion trade-off. As a matter of fact, as shown in [26], the following lower bound, referred to as uncertainty principle for communication compression, holds (if omitted, the base of log\log is assumed to be 222):

Î±â€‹â€‰4b/dâ‰¥1or, equivalently,bâ‰¥dâ€‹12â€‹logâ¡1Î±.formulae-sequenceğ›¼superscript4ğ‘ğ‘‘1or, equivalently,ğ‘ğ‘‘121ğ›¼\alpha\,4^{\nicefrac{{b}}{{d}}}\geq 1\quad\text{or, equivalently,}\quad b\geq d\,\frac{1}{2}\log\frac{1}{\alpha}. (1)

In this work, we investigate this trade-off more deeply. We perform two types of analyses: worst case analysis (WCA) and average case analysis (ACA). Then, capitalizing on this new knowledge, we design new efficient compression schemes. Note that our derivations deal with real numbers, compressed using a finite number of bits. We should keep in mind that numbers are represented by finite-precision, say 32 bits, floats in computers. We can safely omit this aspect in the derivations; we discuss this point in more details in the Appendix.

2.1 Compression operator as composition of encoder and decoder

Generally speaking, compression is a two-sided notion, in the sense that one end encodes the message, while the other end decodes it to estimate the original information. An encoder is any mapping E:â„dâ†’{0,1}âˆ—:ğ¸â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscript01E\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\{0,1\}^{*} which maps a given vector xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} to some finite word from the set of all finite words {0,1}âˆ—superscript01\{0,1\}^{*} with the binary alphabet {0,1}01\{0,1\}. A decoder, on the other hand, is a mapping D:{0,1}âˆ—â†’â„d:ğ·â†’superscript01superscriptâ„ğ‘‘D\colon\{0,1\}^{*}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} which aims to reconstruct the initial vector xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} from the finite binary codeword Eâ€‹(x)ğ¸ğ‘¥E(x). Thus, a compression operator ğ’:â„dâ†’â„d:ğ’â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘{\cal C}\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} can be decomposed into an encoder and decoder so that ğ’â€‹(x)=Dâ€‹(Eâ€‹(x))ğ’ğ‘¥ğ·ğ¸ğ‘¥{\cal C}(x)=D(E(x)). The number of bits needed to transfer a compressed version of xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is the length |Eâ€‹(x)|ğ¸ğ‘¥|E(x)| of the binary word Eâ€‹(x)ğ¸ğ‘¥E(x). In the worst case analysis we are interested in the length of the longest codeword supx,ğ’â€‹(x)|Eâ€‹(x)|subscriptsupremumğ‘¥ğ’ğ‘¥ğ¸ğ‘¥\sup_{x,{\cal C}(x)}|E(x)|, while in average case analysis we investigate the size of the longest expected codeword supxğ”¼ğ’â€‹[|Eâ€‹(x)|]subscriptsupremumğ‘¥subscriptğ”¼ğ’delimited-[]ğ¸ğ‘¥\sup_{x}\mathbb{E}_{{\cal C}}\left[|E(x)|\right].

Notice that a compression operator from any of the three classes requires countably many bits in order to encode points near x=0ğ‘¥0x=0 and x=âˆğ‘¥x=\infty. We address this issue in the Appendix by considering relaxed classes of compression operators capturing finite representation of a single float in machines. From now on, we exclude trivial cases Ï‰=0,Î±âˆˆ{0,1}formulae-sequenceğœ”0ğ›¼01\omega=0,\;\alpha\in\{0,1\} and assume Ï‰>0,Î±âˆˆ(0,1)formulae-sequenceğœ”0ğ›¼01\omega>0,\;\alpha\in(0,1).

2.2 Two senses of optimality for compression

It is worth distinguishing between optimality within a class in a single step of communication and optimality of total communication throughout the optimization process leading to Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-accuracy, e.g. â€–xtâˆ’xâ‹†â€–2â€–x0âˆ’xâ‹†â€–2â‰¤Ïµsuperscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¥â‹†2superscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘¥0superscriptğ‘¥â‹†2italic-Ïµ\frac{\|x^{t}-x^{\star}\|^{2}}{\|x^{0}-x^{\star}\|^{2}}\leq\epsilon for a prescribed Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, where tğ‘¡t is the iteration counter. Our theoretical contributions mainly deal with the first sense of optimality. Regarding the second view of optimality, the following proposition shows that Compressed Gradient Descent (CGD) can converge at significantly different speeds for different operators from ğ”¹â€‹(Î±)ğ”¹ğ›¼\mathbb{B}(\alpha).

Proposition 1.

If ğ’âˆˆğ”¹â€‹(Î±)ğ’ğ”¹ğ›¼\mathcal{C}\in\mathbb{B}(\alpha), the iteration complexity of CGD is 11âˆ’Î±11ğ›¼\frac{1}{1-\alpha} times bigger than for GD; that is CGD needs 11âˆ’Î±11ğ›¼\frac{1}{1-\alpha} times more iterations than GD to obtain the same Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-accuracy. Moreover, if ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C} is additionally unbiased, then only 1+Î±1ğ›¼1+\alpha times more iterations are sufficient.

Thus, if we aim to minimize the total communication complexity ensuring convergence to Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-accuracy, then the optimal operator ğ’âˆ—superscriptğ’{\cal C}^{*} should be either unbiased, or it will need to satisfy not only the direct condition, ğ”¼â€‹[|Eğ’âˆ—â€‹(x)|]â‰¤ğ”¼â€‹[|Eğ’â€‹(x)|]ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¸superscriptğ’ğ‘¥ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¸ğ’ğ‘¥\mathbb{E}[|E_{{\cal C}^{*}}(x)|]\leq\mathbb{E}[|E_{{\cal C}}(x)|] for all operators ğ’âˆˆğ”¹â€‹(Î±)ğ’ğ”¹ğ›¼{\cal C}\in\mathbb{B}(\alpha), but also the additional condition ğ”¼â€‹[|Eğ’âˆ—â€‹(x)|]â‰¤(1âˆ’Î±2)â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[|Eğ’°â€‹(x)|]ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¸superscriptğ’ğ‘¥1superscriptğ›¼2ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¸ğ’°ğ‘¥\mathbb{E}[|E_{{\cal C}^{*}}(x)|]\leq(1-\alpha^{2})\mathbb{E}[|E_{\mathcal{U}}(x)|] for all unbiased operators ğ’°âˆˆğ”¹â€‹(Î±)ğ’°ğ”¹ğ›¼\mathcal{U}\in\mathbb{B}(\alpha). It is important to see that when Î±ğ›¼\alpha is close to 111, then this additional constraint is hard to satisfy when ğ’âˆ—superscriptğ’\mathcal{C}^{*} is not unbiased. For Î±<1ğ›¼1\alpha<1, we show that this is indeed the case by obtaining an optimal biased operator ğ’âˆ—âˆˆğ”¹â€‹(Î±)superscriptğ’ğ”¹ğ›¼\mathcal{C}^{*}\in\mathbb{B}(\alpha), which we call Spherical Compression, and another unbiased one, which we call Sparse Dithering. We show that the latter is more suitable in practice due to its unbiasedness, and hence, convergence occurs in much fewer iterations, and that this is most pronounced when Î±ğ›¼\alpha is close to 1. In addition to being computationally efficient, we show that Sparse Dithering can guarantee reducing the total training communication by â‰ˆ9.9Ã—\approx 9.9\times compared to full precision gradient communication of 323232-bits floats.

2.3 Dimension-tolerant compression schemes.

By dimension-tolerant compression, we mean a collection of operators ğ’Â¯=(ğ’d)dâ‰¥d0Â¯ğ’subscriptsubscriptğ’ğ‘‘ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘‘0\bar{{\cal C}}=\left({\cal C}_{d}\right)_{d\geq d_{0}} that can be used to compress vectors xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} for any dâ‰¥d0ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘‘0d\geq d_{0} and there exists a non-trivial fixed upper bound (Ï‰Â¯<âˆÂ¯ğœ”\bar{\omega}<\infty or Î±Â¯<1Â¯ğ›¼1\bar{\alpha}<1) for variances (Ï‰dsubscriptğœ”ğ‘‘\omega_{d} or Î±dsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘‘\alpha_{d}), i.e. Ï‰dâ‰¤Ï‰Â¯<âˆsubscriptğœ”ğ‘‘Â¯ğœ”\omega_{d}\leq\bar{\omega}<\infty or Î±dâ‰¤Î±Â¯<1subscriptğ›¼ğ‘‘Â¯ğ›¼1\alpha_{d}\leq\bar{\alpha}<1 for any dâ‰¥d0ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘‘0d\geq d_{0}.

The following holds:

    If ğ’Â¯=(ğ’d)dâ‰¥d0Â¯ğ’subscriptsubscriptğ’ğ‘‘ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘‘0\bar{{\cal C}}=\left({\cal C}_{d}\right)_{d\geq d_{0}} is a dimension-tolerant compression composed of operators from ğ•Œâ€‹(Ï‰)ğ•Œğœ”\mathbb{U}(\omega) (ğ”¹â€‹(Î±)ğ”¹ğ›¼\mathbb{B}(\alpha) or â„‚â€‹(Î±)â„‚ğ›¼\mathbb{C}(\alpha)), then there exists a positive constant c>0ğ‘0c>0 (independent of dğ‘‘d) such that for any dâ‰¥d0ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘‘0d\geq d_{0} at least câ€‹dğ‘ğ‘‘cd bits are required in the worst case to encode ğ’dâ€‹(x)âˆˆâ„dsubscriptğ’ğ‘‘ğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘{\cal C}_{d}(x)\in\mathbb{R}^{d} for any xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

  • (ii)

    Let c>0ğ‘0c>0 be a fixed positive constant. Thus, Î˜â€‹(d)Î˜ğ‘‘\Theta(d) bits need to be transmitted in order to bound the variance by a constant. The same asymptotic bound, Î˜â€‹(d)Î˜ğ‘‘\Theta(d) bits per node, on total communication holds for distributed mean estimation [41, 20, 33].

2.4 Compressed learning algorithms

To highlight the importance of investigating the communication-variance trade-off of compression operators, we present how these operators affect the performance of compressed learning algorithms. Similarly, for compression operators from ğ”¹â€‹(Î±)ğ”¹ğ›¼\mathbb{B}(\alpha) or â„‚â€‹(Î±)â„‚ğ›¼\mathbb{C}(\alpha), the parameter Î±ğ›¼\alpha controls the slowdown. Table 1 summarizes iteration complexities of various learning algorithms exploiting compressed communication and exposes the dependence of the variance (Ï‰ğœ”\omega and Î±ğ›¼\alpha) of compression operator. The conclusion from this discussion and from Table 1 is that to facilitate fast and communication-efficient training process, one needs to design compression operators minimizing both variance and number of encoding bits. This is the motivation of our work. Therefore, compression operators developed in this paper can be incorporated in any compressed learning algorithm, including all the ones in Table 1.

3 Worst-Case Analysis

We start our analysis of compression operators with respect to the number of encoding bits in the worst case. First, we show that the lower bound (1) for the class ğ”¹â€‹(Î±)ğ”¹ğ›¼\mathbb{B}(\alpha) is asymptotically tight for any Î±âˆˆ(0,1)ğ›¼01\alpha\in(0,1). Then, we design an efficient compression operator from â„‚â€‹(Î±)â„‚ğ›¼\mathbb{C}(\alpha), Sparse Dithering, which is within a small constant factor of being optimal. Finally, we derive asymptotically tighter lower and upper bounds.

3.1 Asymptotic tightness of the lower bound (1)

First, we show that for any fixed Î±âˆˆ(0,1)ğ›¼01\alpha\in(0,1), the constant 1 in the lower bound (1) is not improvable. We denote by ğ•Šd={xâˆˆâ„d:â€–xâ€–=1}superscriptğ•Šğ‘‘conditional-setğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘normğ‘¥1\mathbb{S}^{d}=\{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}\ :\ \|x\|=1\} the unit sphere of â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Theorem 2.

For any given Î±âˆˆ(0,1)ğ›¼01\alpha\in(0,1) and dâ‰¥3ğ‘‘3d\geq 3 there exists an Î±ğ›¼\alpha-contractive compression operator ğ’:ğ•Šdâ†’â„d:ğ’â†’superscriptğ•Šğ‘‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘{\cal C}\colon\mathbb{S}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d}, such that

Î±â€‹â€‰4b/dâ‰¤(1600â€‹d2â€‹logâ¡d)2/d,ğ›¼superscript4ğ‘ğ‘‘superscript1600superscriptğ‘‘2ğ‘‘2ğ‘‘\alpha\,4^{\nicefrac{{b}}{{d}}}\leq\left(1600d^{2}\log d\right)^{\nicefrac{{2}}{{d}}}, (6)

where bğ‘b is the number of bits (in the worst case) needed to encode ğ’â€‹(x)âˆˆâ„dğ’ğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘{\cal C}(x)\in\mathbb{R}^{d} for any unit vector xâˆˆğ•Šdğ‘¥superscriptğ•Šğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{S}^{d}. In particular, for any Î±âˆˆ(0,1)ğ›¼01\alpha\in(0,1) and Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0 one can choose dğ‘‘d large enough such that compression operator ğ’ğ’{\cal C} satisfies

Î±â€‹â€‰4b/d<1+Ïµ.ğ›¼superscript4ğ‘ğ‘‘1italic-Ïµ\alpha\,4^{\nicefrac{{b}}{{d}}}<1+\epsilon. (7)
Remark 1.

Using covering results from [11] (see Theorem 1), the constant 1600 in (6) can be reduced up to 2. Using tighter inequalities for the Î“Î“\Gamma function, the term d2superscriptğ‘‘2d^{2} can be improved as well. However, these will not improve the inequality (7). Notice that the right hand side of (6) approaches 1 quickly; for d=103ğ‘‘superscript103d=10^{3} it is â‰ˆ1.047absent1.047\approx 1.047.

Note that the compression operator in this theorem acts on ğ•Šdsuperscriptğ•Šğ‘‘\mathbb{S}^{d}, not â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}. However, allocating an additional constant amount of bits for the norm â€–xâ€–normğ‘¥\|x\| (say 313131 bits in float32 format), we can extend the domain of compression operators without hurting the asymptotic tightness. Thus, the lower bound (1) is asymptotically tight for the class ğ”¹â€‹(Î±)ğ”¹ğ›¼\mathbb{B}(\alpha).

Although the construction of this theorem yields an optimal contractive operator, it is infeasible to apply in high dimensions.

3.2 New Compressor: Sparse Dithering (SD)

With the aim of constructing both optimal and efficient compression operators, we introduce a new compression schemeâ€“Sparse Dithering (SD)â€“which is efficient in high dimension and nearly optimal. In some sense, SD can viewed as an effective combination of Top-kğ‘˜k sparsification [3] and random dithering with uniform levels [2]. The essential novelty is the encoding scheme and better upper bound on the number of communicated bits. In this section, we present a deterministic and hence biased version of SD.

Theorem 4.

4 Average-Case Analysis

Now we switch to the average-case analysis for the class â„‚â€‹(Î±)â„‚ğ›¼\mathbb{C}(\alpha). First, we prove a lower bound for communicated bits in expectation. Then we analyze the randomized version of Sparse Dithering, which, having better theoretical guarantees than random dithering, is suboptimal in this analysis. Finally, we present a new compression operator from â„‚â€‹(Î±)â„‚ğ›¼\mathbb{C}(\alpha), Spherical Compression, which is provably optimal.

4.1 Lower bound on average communication

In this section, we consider compression operators from â„‚â€‹(Î±)â„‚ğ›¼\mathbb{C}(\alpha) and investigate the trade-off between normalized variance Î±ğ›¼\alpha and expected number of bits

B=supâ€–xâ€–=1ğ”¼ğ’â€‹[|Eâ€‹(x)|].ğµsubscriptsupremumnormğ‘¥1subscriptğ”¼ğ’delimited-[]ğ¸ğ‘¥B=\sup_{\|x\|=1}\mathbb{E}_{{\cal C}}\left[|E(x)|\right].

In other words, we study the trade-off for strictly Î±ğ›¼\alpha-contractive operators that encode any unit vector with no more than BğµB bits in expectation. In such a setting, we show the following lower bound on BğµB.

Theorem 6.

Let ğ’âˆˆâ„‚â€‹(Î±)ğ’â„‚ğ›¼{\cal C}\in\mathbb{C}(\alpha) be a compression operator such that ğ’â€‹(x)âˆˆâ„dğ’ğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘{\cal C}(x)\in\mathbb{R}^{d} can be transferred with BğµB bits in expectation for any unit vector xâˆˆğ•Šdğ‘¥superscriptğ•Šğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{S}^{d}. 4.2 Randomized version of Sparse Dithering

Here we randomize Sparse Dithering to make it unbiased and estimate the number of encoding bits it needs in expectation. First we decompose the to-be-compressed vector xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} into the magnitude and unit direction u=x/â€–xâ€–ğ‘¢ğ‘¥normğ‘¥u=x/\|x\| as before. Theorem 7.

Randomized SD compression with parameter Î½=Ï‰ğœˆğœ”\nu=\omega belongs to ğ•Œâ€‹(Ï‰)ğ•Œğœ”\mathbb{U}(\omega), communicating at most

As mentioned earlier, SD is similar to random dithering with uniform levels, namely with dğ‘‘\sqrt{d} levels. 4.3 New Compressor: Spherical Compression (SC)

It can be shown that randomized SD compression discussed in the previous section is suboptimal with respect to the lower bound of Theorem 6. Here we provide a simple compression operatorâ€“Spherical Compression (SC)â€“that achieves this lower bound with less than 333 overhead bits.

Construction and variance bound. As before, we transmit the magnitude and direction separately. For a given unit vector xâˆˆğ•Šdğ‘¥superscriptğ•Šğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{S}^{d}, SC generates a sequence (xt)t=1Tsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘¡1ğ‘‡(x^{t})_{t=1}^{T} of i.i.d. points with â€–xtâ€–2=1âˆ’Î±superscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡21ğ›¼\|x^{t}\|^{2}=1-\alpha, and terminates once â€–xTâˆ’xâ€–2â‰¤Î±superscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‡ğ‘¥2ğ›¼\|x^{T}-x\|^{2}\leq\alpha for some Tâ‰¥1ğ‘‡1T\geq 1. The last generated point xTsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‡x^{T} is the compressed version of xğ‘¥x we need to communicate, that is ğ’â€‹(x)=xTğ’ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‡{\cal C}(x)=x^{T}. It follows directly from this construction that ğ’âˆˆâ„‚â€‹(Î±)ğ’â„‚ğ›¼{\cal C}\in\mathbb{C}(\alpha).

Encoding scheme. The crucial part of the encoding scheme is that it is enough to communicate only Tğ‘‡T. Indeed, the communication process is the following. Importantly, the emitter and receiver have agreed on using the same random seed for generating i.i.d. points (xt)superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡(x^{t}), before the compression of any vector is performed.

Then, upon receiving the number of trials Tğ‘‡T, the decoder can reproduce the same sequence x1,x2,â€¦,xTsuperscriptğ‘¥1superscriptğ‘¥2â€¦superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‡x^{1},x^{2},\dots,x^{T} and recover xTsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‡x^{T}. Consequently, it remains to encode the random integer Tğ‘‡T into a binary code.

Upper bound on BğµB. First we show that Tğ‘‡T follows a geometric distribution with parameter p=Pâ€‹(Î±,d)ğ‘ğ‘ƒğ›¼ğ‘‘p=P(\alpha,d). Indeed, Tğ‘‡T can be viewed as the number of trials before the first success happens after a series of failures.

Appendix

Appendix A Discussion on Finite Precision Floats

In the paper, we formally consider compression of arbitrary vectors of â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}, but in practice, in computers, real numbers are represented with finite-precision floats, typically using 32 bits. As a consequence, a nonzero real cannot be too small, too large, and its precision is limited. Compression, like every operation, amounts to a sequence of elementary arithmetic operations, each being exact only up to so-called â€˜machine precisionâ€™, which is difficult to model. Thus, we could restrict ourselves to vectors in {0}âˆª{x:râ‰¤â€–xâ€–â‰¤R}0conditional-setğ‘¥ğ‘Ÿnormğ‘¥ğ‘…\{0\}\cup\{x:r\leq\|x\|\leq R\} for some 0<r<R0ğ‘Ÿğ‘…0<r<R, instead of the whole space â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}, but this would not account for the finite precision of floats, and since this set is not stable by arithmetic operations, this would not be enough to model the setting in all rigor. So, we prefer to stick with the general setting of â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d} throughout the paper, since there is no issue with limit cases of very large or very small nonzero numbers, that would deserve a particular discussion; the finite precision makes them automatically irrelevant in practice. In other words, the finite representation of reals is not more problematic with compression than for any learning or optimization task, and more generally for the numerical implementation of any mathematical algorithm.

In particular, considering floats with 32 bits, a non-compressed vector xğ‘¥x of â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d} is actually represented using 32â€‹d32ğ‘‘32d bits. When we decompose xğ‘¥x into its â€˜gainâ€™ â€–xâ€–normğ‘¥\|x\| and â€˜shapeâ€™ x/â€–xâ€–âˆˆğ•Šdğ‘¥normğ‘¥superscriptğ•Šğ‘‘x/\|x\|\in\mathbb{S}^{d}, there is no trickery in considering that â€–xâ€–normğ‘¥\|x\| is represented using 31 bits (the sign bit can be omitted) and that x/â€–xâ€–ğ‘¥normğ‘¥x/\|x\| is actually compressed. The multiplication by â€–xâ€–normğ‘¥\|x\| at decompression has finite precision, just like any arithmetic operation.

Appendix B Proofs for Section 2

B.1 Relaxed classes of compression operators

As mentioned in the paper and in AppendixÂ A, any operator from ğ•Œâ€‹(Ï‰),ğ”¹â€‹(Î±),â„‚â€‹(Î±)ğ•Œğœ”ğ”¹ğ›¼â„‚ğ›¼\mathbb{U}(\omega),\,\mathbb{B}(\alpha),\,\mathbb{C}(\alpha) cannot be encoded with a finite number of bits. For example, in the case of ğ”¹â€‹(Î±)ğ”¹ğ›¼\mathbb{B}(\alpha), the inequality (4) breaks near x=0ğ‘¥0x=0 and â€–xâ€–â†’âˆâ†’normğ‘¥\|x\|\rightarrow\infty. However, in practice, machine floats have finite precision and we do not deal with nonzero values that are too small and too large. To reflect this practical aspect into the theory, we adjust the definition of Î±ğ›¼\alpha-contractive compressors ğ”¹â€‹(Î±)ğ”¹ğ›¼\mathbb{B}(\alpha) and consider the following class instead. For the sake of concreteness, we carry out the discussion for the class ğ”¹â€‹(Î±)ğ”¹ğ›¼\mathbb{B}(\alpha) only and note that analogous observations can be adopted for other two classes.

Definition 5 (Practical Î±ğ›¼\alpha-contractive compressions).

which is equivalent to (6). Finally, since 1â‰¤ddâ†’11ğ‘‘ğ‘‘â†’11\leq\sqrt[d]{d}\to 1 as dâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘‘d\to\infty, we can make the right hand side of (6) smaller than 1+Ïµ1italic-Ïµ1+\epsilon for any fixed Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon just by choosing a large dğ‘‘d.

C.3 Tighter bounds on minimal communication: Proofs of Theorems 4 and 5

The first motivation for this is that even though the uncetainty principle (1) is strong for constant Î±ğ›¼\alpha, it is not tight when Î±ğ›¼\alpha goes to 1 as dğ‘‘d goes to infinity. In particular, for Î±=dâˆ’1dğ›¼ğ‘‘1ğ‘‘\alpha=\frac{d-1}{d}, it says that the number of bits is at least dâ€‹logâ¡(1âˆ’1/d)/2ğ‘‘11ğ‘‘2d\log(1-1/d)/2, which is constant. However, we can show that when Î±<1ğ›¼1\alpha<1, one needs at least logâ¡(d)ğ‘‘\log(d) bits. This explains why there is no way to only communicate a fixed number of bits per round while still having Î±<1ğ›¼1\alpha<1. Moreover, we will compute an explicit estimate of bâˆ—â€‹(Î±,d)superscriptğ‘ğ›¼ğ‘‘b^{*}(\alpha,d), as a function of dğ‘‘d and Î±ğ›¼\alpha only, with a very low error of 12â€‹logâ¡logâ¡d+C12ğ‘‘ğ¶\frac{1}{2}\log{\log{d}}+C for some absolute constant Cğ¶C.

Proof of Theorem 4.

Proving the result is equivalent to proving that the surface of the unit sphere cannot be covered by less than dğ‘‘d smaller, identical balls. We can prove this easily by induction. To make the induction step, let us assume, without loss of generality, that one of the smaller balls is centered on the positive x1subscriptğ‘¥1x_{1} axis. Since the radius of this smaller ball is less than 1, the unit (dâˆ’1)ğ‘‘1(d-1)-dimensional sphere with x1=0subscriptğ‘¥10x_{1}=0 is disjoint from the first smaller ball, which means, by induction, that it will itself require at least dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 additional smaller balls, leading to the desired result. âˆ

In fact, the previous result can be used to obtain the following result.

Definition 8.

For a covering of the surface of the unit sphere using identical spherical caps, we define the density of the cover to be the average number of caps covering a point on the surface of the unit sphere. Identically, this is equal to the number of spherical caps used multiplied by the fraction of the unit sphere covered by a single spherical cap.

Theorem 10.

There exists an absolute constant BğµB such that if the surface of the unit sphere is covered with identical smaller spherical caps, then the density of the covering is at least Bâ€‹dğµğ‘‘Bd.

Proof.

We split this into two cases. The first case is when the radius of the spherical cap is larger than 1âˆ’1d11ğ‘‘\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{d}}. In this case, each spherical cover will cover at least a fraction of Aâ€‹(d)=Probâ€‹(x1â‰¥1d)ğ´ğ‘‘Probsubscriptğ‘¥11ğ‘‘A(d)={\rm Prob}\left(x_{1}\geq\frac{1}{\sqrt{d}}\right) where xğ‘¥x is chosen uniformly from the surface of the unit sphere. One can easily show that there exists C1>0subscriptğ¶10C_{1}>0 such that Aâ€‹(d)>C1ğ´ğ‘‘subscriptğ¶1A(d)>C_{1} for all d. Indeed, it is enough to see that Aâ€‹(d)>0ğ´ğ‘‘0A(d)>0 for all dğ‘‘d and that Aâ€‹(d)ğ´ğ‘‘A(d) approaches 1âˆ’Ï•â€‹(1)1italic-Ï•11-\phi(1) where Ï•italic-Ï•\phi is the CDF of a standard normal. Combining this bound with the previous result of requiring at least dğ‘‘d caps to cover the surface of the unit sphere, the density is at least C1â€‹dsubscriptğ¶1ğ‘‘C_{1}d when the radius of the spherical cap is at least 1âˆ’1d11ğ‘‘\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{d}}.
In the second case, when the radius of the spherical cap is less than 1âˆ’1d<1âˆ’1d+111ğ‘‘11ğ‘‘1\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{d}}<\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{d+1}}, The Coxeterâ€“Fewâ€“Rogers â€œsimplexâ€ bound shows [11] that the density is at least C2â€‹dsubscriptğ¶2ğ‘‘C_{2}d for some absolute constant C2subscriptğ¶2C_{2}. Choosing B=minâ¡(C1,C2)ğµsubscriptğ¶1subscriptğ¶2B=\min\left(C_{1},C_{2}\right) gives us the desired result. âˆ

Theorem 11 (see [11]).

There exists an absolute constant Ağ´A such that for any dğ‘‘d and any spherical radius r<1ğ‘Ÿ1r<1, there exists a cover for the surface of the unit sphere with smaller, identical spherical caps of radius rğ‘Ÿr such that the density of the covering is at most Aâ€‹dâ€‹logâ¡dğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘‘Ad\log{d}.

Lemma 4.

If â€–xâ€–=1normğ‘¥1\|x\|=1 and â€–vâˆ’xâ€–2â‰¤Î±superscriptnormğ‘£ğ‘¥2ğ›¼\|v-x\|^{2}\leq\alpha for some tğ‘¡t, then for vâ€²=1âˆ’Î±â€‹vâ€–vâ€–superscriptğ‘£â€²1ğ›¼ğ‘£normğ‘£v^{\prime}=\frac{\sqrt{1-\alpha}v}{\|v\|}, one has â€–xâˆ’vâ€²â€–2â‰¤Î±superscriptnormğ‘¥superscriptğ‘£â€²2ğ›¼\|x-v^{\prime}\|^{2}\leq\alpha. Proof.

The initial condition is equivalent to 1âˆ’Î±+â€–vâ€–2â‰¤2â€‹âŸ¨v,xâŸ©1ğ›¼superscriptnormğ‘£22ğ‘£ğ‘¥1-\alpha+\|v\|^{2}\leq 2\langle v,x\rangle which, using AM-GM, implies that 2â€‹1âˆ’Î±â€‹â€–vâ€–â‰¤2â€‹âŸ¨v,xâŸ©21ğ›¼normğ‘£2ğ‘£ğ‘¥2\sqrt{1-\alpha}\|v\|\leq 2\langle v,x\rangle, which can be rearranged to to look like 1âˆ’Î±+â€–vâ€²â€–2â‰¤2â€‹âŸ¨vâ€²,xâŸ©1ğ›¼superscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘£â€²22superscriptğ‘£â€²ğ‘¥1-\alpha+\|v^{\prime}\|^{2}\leq 2\langle v^{\prime},x\rangle or â€–vâ€²âˆ’xâ€–2â‰¤Î±superscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘£â€²ğ‘¥2ğ›¼\|v^{\prime}-x\|^{2}\leq\alpha, as desired. âˆ

The above discussion leads us to our next result on bâˆ—â€‹(Î±,d)superscriptğ‘ğ›¼ğ‘‘b^{*}(\alpha,d), which is an important quantity to study.
